At one time, the World-Honored One was among the great assembly, surrounded by devas and humans, gazing up at the World-Honored One's face, never taking their eyes off him for a moment.
Then, the great assembly spoke this verse in front of the Buddha:
We take refuge in the Omniscient One, the Most Venerable in the Three Realms,
Proclaiming the subtle and wonderful sounds, widely benefiting all sentient beings.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the great assembly and spoke this verse:
If there are sentient beings who do not kill and give fearlessness,
With a compassionate mind, able to endure, dignified and incomparable in lifespan.ğŸ”½If, with regard to sentient beings,
one regards them as one's own parents,
One can then avoid taking what is not given, and wisdom and blessings will be immeasurable.
If one practices good physical actions, leaving desires and the mind being firm,
Not observing the wonderful form of a woman, one will be liberated from all evil destinies.
The world should be distanced, and liberation can be joyfully realized,
Like gold ore that is covered, the inherent nature is originally pure.
Afflictions cannot subdue it, and supreme touch gives rise to love,
Good and evil matters are not distinguished, and the suffering of a floating life is the greatest.
Suffering and joy still arise from the mind, and gain and loss also occur in events,
The separation and union of good and evil friends, the principle of cause and effect is impartial.
Subduing the disturbances of the senses, the essential practice of an impartial mind,
Benefiting all sentient beings, this is called the practice of a bhiká¹£u.
Åšramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, afflictions should be subdued and eliminated,
Cultivating wisdom and increasing it, causing the mind to be undistracted,
The principle of nirvana must be realized, and all suffering should be abandoned.
Strive to arouse the mind of right view, the Buddha says this is difficult to compare!
Liberated from all cyclic existences, Mount Sumeru-like love is unshakable,
Equal to the fragrance of sandalwood, the taste of nectar is incomparable.
Although one obtains the highest offerings, such as exquisite clothes,
Do not be attached to greed and love, be content and joyful.
Like grass burned by fire, know it is not ultimate,
Make offerings to cultivate merit and wisdom, water and fire cannot invade.
The fruit of pure karma and true wisdom, the river of water will never run dry,
Do not crave for various realms, the Buddha says this is the practice of bhiká¹£us.
Delightfully seeking various wisdoms, always manifest in accordance,
Comprehending the true Dharma, do not fall into cyclic existences.
If a person seeks pure dharmas, causing the mind not to be scattered,
Generously bestowing all realms, the fire of the kalpa cannot destroy them.
Ignorance is the root of all existence, samsara arises from this.
Afflictions should be diligently subdued and eliminated, this is the true Muni's practice.
Delighting in practicing patience, being dignified and free from enmity,
Is the cause for the Sage's wondrous marks, seeing which brings joy to the mind.
Forests and wilderness are free from confusion and noise, delighting in them brings joy to the mind.
Always taking a single meal in a bowl, this is called the practice of a bhiká¹£u.
Liberation is the most blissful, the three evil paths are the most painful.
True suchness is free from this and that, it cannot be attained through contemplation.
Benefiting others with impartial actions, always gentle and straightforward,
Always in accord with right practice, far from all wrong attachments.ğŸ”½The mind faculty delights in attachment, the mind faculty is called supreme.
The mind faculty can be swift, the mind faculty can bring joy.
The gÄthÄs expound this, able to create and also able to speak,
Shaking off all afflictions, the fruits of karma well understood.
Understanding gains and losses, able to proceed to wondrous enlightenment,
All sentient beings, the foremost among the six faculties.
Joyfully abiding in the forest, far from all enemies,
Understanding these six faculties, the correct practice emerges from this.
Always dwelling in the state of equanimity, shaking off all karmic hindrances,
Just as the sky is not tainted by wind and clouds.
Well guarding body, speech, and mind, always in accord with right view,
Wisdom like the light of a lamp, the host of demons cannot destroy it.
Not harming beings is called good, compassion and benefit are profound,
The deportment is without transgression, only then can one dwell in the mind of a bhiká¹£u.
The eye is bound by the objects of form, obstructed, the rest not turning,
Afflictions bind sentient beings, unable to leave the three realms.
The subtle and marvelous wisdom of truth and convention, skillful means are still rare,
Praised in common by all Buddhas, the application is difficult to fathom.
Listening widely to seek liberation, greed and anger cannot go against,
Well guarding the three karmas of the body, subduing and eliminating them so they do not arise.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this verse, he addressed the great assembly, saying:

If there are sentient beings bound by afflictions, cycling in the three realms and experiencing various sufferings, if they practice the ten wholesome deeds, they will attain the fruits of humans and gods, loving and delighting in them.
It is like the full moon, free from obstructions, pure and incomparable, seeing it brings joy;
Also, like firewood, fire can burn it. Such evil karma should be subdued and eliminated, leaving the three realms of birth and death, liberation from suffering;
Also, like a flying bird, freed from bondage, it is unrestricted.

If sentient beings do not create karma, they will transcend the three realms and realize the principle of the two emptinesses. Suffering and distress will not invade them, and they will not be tainted by greed and anger. They will understand the cycle of rebirth.

It is like the light of a lamp illuminating objects. When correctly cognizing, one is always uninterrupted. Free from all wrong attachments, one delights in tranquility. Under a tree in a charnel ground, one abandons all evil and befriends the good.
Monks, in this way, cultivating the practice of leaving the household life, one should not be attached to any delightful objects of the senses;
One should not enjoy dwellings, avoid buying and selling and false speech, not enjoy singing and dancing, abandon hatred and love, and eat one meal a day in the forest;

Always delight in seeking supreme enlightenment, avoid taking what is not given, keep to rags for robes, be content and joyful, dwell in the forest and wilderness in tranquil contemplation, and be free from scattered thoughts, greed, anger, and so forth;

Always practicing loving-kindness and benefiting sentient beings, far from ignorance and cultivating wisdom, free from afflictions and karma, liberated from birth and death, cultivating the eightfold noble path, with tranquility manifest, destroying all afflictions and suffering.
Bhiká¹£us, you should cultivate and practice in this way, firm in the roots of goodness, far from tainted desires, with single-minded focus, delighting in suchness;
Various wisdoms increase and flourish, perfecting the pure Dharma without outflows, understanding that defiled outflows are illusory and unreal.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

If there are bhiká¹£us who abide in the brahmacarya, pure and gentle, well cultivating samatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ, delighting in meditative absorption, playing in the forests, far from all taints, penetrating delusion, also like flying birds with their shadows following in the sky.

The bhiká¹£us are also like this. The three robes follow the body, well cultivating equality, always contemplating the true Dharma to subdue and eliminate afflictions, in accord with wisdom, seeking to see the path, up to the other shore, ultimately nirvÄá¹‡a.
Bhiká¹£us should know, contemplating in this way, abiding in joy, but always fearing saá¹ƒsÄra, old age, sickness, and death.
Like the asuras and other heavenly beings, joyfully and respectfully obtaining the excellent saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« and bowl, not needing other vessels;
guarding the pure conduct, not allowing it to be violated, pure and spotless, not attached to various flavors and benefits.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
If sentient beings abandon the compassionate mind, with arrogance and heedlessness, burning away all goodness, it is difficult to exhaust the various defilements.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If one abandons compassion and diligence, being associated with ignorance and arrogance,
Tranquility will not manifest, and there will be no way to eliminate the defilements.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
If there are people who, regarding bedding, should not delight in the finest and softest.
Awakening to the root of the delusion of ignorance, the afflictions arise accordingly;

Namely, this ignorance pervades all defiled minds. If they are absent, one should not be deluded or dark. Understanding all dharmas, and attaining meditative concentration, one should exhaust all defilements.
Then the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
If you wish to practice walking meditation, be in the forest, tranquil and undisturbed. Regarding all that is unlawful, alcohol, sexual desires, and so forth, you should not delight in them.
Bhiká¹£us, in this way, if the hosts of MÄra, due to the bondage of karma, disturb the practice of goodness, it is like a person drinking poison, suffering the consequences of their own doing;
You now break the precepts, engage in wrong livelihood, are bound by afflictions, and will fall into the great hells to experience various sufferings.
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that when going for alms, if you see a woman, think of her as a poisonous snake;

Concentrate your mind and thoughts, contemplate the true Dharma, do not seek fame, gain, or wonderful realms, be free from the bondage of karma, and keep your mind in equanimity, without engaging in slander.
If you enter a village, think of it as a forest;
When begging for food and drink, think of it as a way to cure illness;
When afflictions arise, think of it as a burning forest;
When seeking wonderful Dharma, think of it as heading towards the right path;
When lying down on a bed, think of it as a frightened deer;
When entering various meditative absorptions, think of it as strolling in a garden;
When seeing an arhat, think of him as a field of merit.
Do not delight in realms, verbal disputes, but always seek liberation.
If kings and ministers benefit and associate with you, do not crave for wonderful food and drink.
Benefactors may always deceive for fame and gain, but your mind should skillfully avoid giving rise to anger.

They delight in dwellings, associate with the powerful, like fish in water, dwelling there without abandoning it, staying far from spiritual friends, confused and turned away from the truth, seeking out illusions like a lamp, a dream, or lightning, thinking it is liberation.
They respect the wrong path, always practicing reverence, unable to understand the supreme truth.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
You should know and be aware, delighting in walking meditation, in meditative concentration and wisdom, always practicing loving-kindness, seeking the supreme true liberation.
Attaining right view, penetrating all dharmas, always cultivating patience and diligence, abandoning greed, anger, and all distractions.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
You should delight in all sentient beings, recollecting and taking pity on them, causing them to leave behind delusions and all bonds, and be liberated from suffering.
Bhiká¹£us should know that regarding all objects, be free from defilement and harm.
It is like the nature of gold, which is free from impurities.
Bhiká¹£us should know that whether going to close friends or to those who are not close, one should be free from greed and anger, and understand what is beneficial and harmful.

Whether it is a sin or not, whether it is peaceful or difficult, one should skillfully subdue [others] and expound the essential Dharma, guiding them with superiority or inferiority according to their sharpness or dullness, intelligence or foolishness, and admonishing them with the correct teachings.

Bhiká¹£us should know that in the forest, while walking, in a quiet place, while practicing meditation, abandoning faults and nonvirtues, always delighting in true suchness, understanding and believing in cause and effect, the distinctions between superiority and inferiority;
Far from all poisons, subduing the faculties, not giving rise to faults and nonvirtues, in accord with wisdom, causing the mind to rejoice, and ceasing slander.
Like the ocean, very deep, in accord with the inexhaustible, the mind and intention firm, not giving rise to doubts, not greedy for wonderful forms, compassionate and impartial;

He should timely expound well the false and true nature of the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm, not speaking of worldly right and wrong words, and be far removed from the various realms of faults and afflictions.
It is like various poisons and mud, do not allow them to invade and harm.
Liberated from the cycle of birth and death, far removed from ignorance, with meditative concentration and wisdom, expounding the supreme Dharma and meaning with eloquence, free from false inversion;
Do not allow any dust and defilements to stain, all that is done is for the benefit of all;
In the Sangha, do not give rise to bodily, verbal, or mental actions that go against, be free from entanglements, do not seek humans or gods;
Cultivate all wholesome actions, not for fame or gain, heading towards nirvana.
Bhiká¹£us should know, always avoid bad friends and do not do any wrong, always with a compassionate mind, observe equally;
With a gentle mind and body, protect the precepts with purity, and accord with the truth.
Free from the fear of separation from one's wife, not confused in cyclic existence and various meditative absorptions, understanding impermanence, with mastery of the wisdom of emptiness.
The Brahma-assembly gods, abiding in meditative absorption, headed towards nirvana.
Listening to the wonderful Dharma, understanding the truth, they rejoiced and leaped with joy.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The fruits of good and evil karma, what is done is definitely experienced.
One binds oneself like a silkworm, no different.
Bitter, astringent, and sweet, all suffering and afflictions,
Like a shadow always following, drinking poison to harm oneself.
At that time, after the World-Honored One spoke this verse, he told the bhiká¹£us:

If there are sentient beings who skillfully cultivate wisdom, destroy the fire of afflictions, abide in the brahma-conduct, delight in the Three Jewels, see and hear with joy, do not give rise to greed or anger, and have the thought of liberation;
Thoroughly understanding and reaching the unmoving, heading towards the true, peacefully abiding in the supreme;
Free from old age, sickness, death, and all cyclic existences, afflictions, and enemies that continue without interruption.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
If one cultivates the brahmacarya in a quiet place, heading towards natural wisdom, the devas and BrahmÄ assemblies will always come to be close, pay homage, and make offerings.
Why is it so?
Loving and delighting in the brahmacarya can destroy cyclic existence, be far from afflictions, make the mind subdued, abandon darkness and all enemies, and prevent them from harming.
It is just like dry grass being free from the burning of fire. Abandoning afflictions is also like this.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

If there are people who are confused about the realms and indulge the faculties, going against nirvÄá¹‡a, with the mind not being impartial, always engaging in the causes of suffering, bound by wrong views, and unable to subdue all afflictions;
They gather vast resources, their greedy minds blazing, the supreme field of merit, ignorant and deluded, never having any realization.

If they encounter a Dharma teacher who skillfully opens and transforms them, they will be far removed from various delusions and attachments such as greed, extinguish the raging flames and be free from all afflictions, head towards the supreme nectar-like wonderful Dharma, and abide in the supreme.
Good friends and acquaintances, loving and enjoying meditation, cultivating wisdom, afflictions like mountains yet able to destroy them.
Abiding in pure wisdom, abandoning all ignorance and leaving behind cyclic existence, attaining wonderful karmic rewards.
Supreme in wisdom, cultivating various excellent practices, the mind continuum.
Content with few desires, extinguishing wrong attachments, all bonds and clinging completely abandoned.
Like a fish swallowing a hook, greedy for the taste, binding itself;

Sentient beings are also like this. They love and enjoy the five desires, constantly not letting go, extensively creating various karmic actions, transmigrating in the cycle of birth and death without cease, deluded and defiled by causes, the distinctions of the various destinies are endless.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If a person creates evil karma, they will revolve in the suffering of hell,
Hungry ghosts and animals, sinking without end.
The hells of Saá¹ƒjÄ«va, KÄlasÅ«tra, Saá¹ƒghÄta, and Raurava,
The hells of Tapana, PratÄpana, and AvÄ«ci;
The suffering of difficult and evil karma, thorns growing sixteen inches long,
The four walls and four gates are all made of iron.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:

The flames and fires in those hells are blazing, extremely violent and continuous, difficult to subdue for hundreds of yojanas, with terrifying shapes and colors, and the extremely evil sounds heard are all painful and distressing.

When sentient beings with evil karma fall into this hell, their heads hang down and their feet are up, and in an instant they are born there and experience various sufferings, burning and burning, crying day and night, making great evil sounds;
like fish on a spit, their skin and flesh are scorched and rotten, filled with darkness everywhere, and their minds are confused.
The sinners see the great fire burning in the realm of Yama, confused and fainting.
Those who commit the same karma are placed in one hell, each person bound, the jailers pulling and dragging them, suffering unbearably and without interruption.
If a person has little wisdom and falsely commits crimes, because of this they revolve, and enemies gather to experience the suffering of hell.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Why are these people in the realm of Yama, bound and suffering so much?
At that time, the Buddha told the monks:

These people always slander the true Dharma, do not give rise to faith and acceptance, do not understand cause and effect, are confused by the hells and do not fear them, and give rise to the fire of afflictions that burns away all goodness.
Because of these karmic causes, they fall into the realm of Yama and experience such suffering, with the utmost fire difficulty without interruption;
hatred and enmity, foolish darkness, according to karma they experience, when karma is exhausted they will leave.
The Buddha told the monks:
If there are people who deceive and lie;
addicted to others' wives and daughters, unable to let go, bound by birth blindness, always covering the light, unable to understand.
At that time, the monks again said to the Buddha:
Why are people born lowly, foolish, and ignorant, and what causes lead to such results?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
In the past, due to the mind of self-importance, despising the virtuous, stinginess, and jealousy, he received this retribution.
If there are people who create discord between others and do evil, due to this cause and condition, they will fall into the hells.
If reborn among humans, they will lack children, lose their wealth, be separated from their acquaintances, and when their lives are about to end, they will be delirious and terrified;
Their relatives will guard them, but they will be confused by the realms and unable to understand.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
One creates and then receives oneself. The harm and sin are for sentient beings.
The violent and evil suffering instruments are many. Only when the karma is exhausted can one escape.
In the world, one creates various karmas. The good and bad always follow.
It is like a flower having fragrance. The near and far all follow each other.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
It is like flying birds perching in forests and trees, gathering and dispersing is not constant;
Parents and relatives are also like this.
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
If there are people who, in a quiet place, focus their thoughts and contemplate, cultivating good deeds, abandoning foolishness and darkness, fishing rods, snares, and violent evil and unlawful acts;
When they are about to die, their body and mind are without distress, free from all fear, and they will be reborn in the heavens;

Food, drink, and clothing are freely available to them, their retinue and palace are all perfect, they are intelligent and wise, and their resources, gardens, and forests are lacking in nothing, their lifespan and appearance are perfect and complete.
If there are people who deceive themselves and deceive the world, scolding and insulting their male and female relatives, friends, and acquaintances, and widely committing various wrongs;
After they die, they will fall into the evil paths and experience immeasurable suffering;
If they are reborn in the human realm, they will be poor and lowly, lacking in clothing and food, and their children and relatives will all abandon them;
deluded by falsehood, they do not understand cause and effect, and afflictions such as greed and hatred constantly arise;
they have never cultivated wholesome deeds and always associate with bad friends and non-dharma.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
In hell, one experiences various sufferings, burned by karma-born flames;
In the human realm, one is bound by suffering, all created by one's own mind;
Transmigrating within the three realms, coming and going like a circling ant,
Karmic fruits mutually serve as conditions, continuing on endlessly.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this verse, he told the bhiká¹£us:
Only by attaining the holy fruits can one escape the cycle of rebirth, be unattached, and experience the bliss of freedom, unshakable by karma and its fruits.

If there are people who give rise to the afflictions of greed and hatred and commit various misdeeds, they will fall into hell, where fierce flames will burn their entire bodies, causing them to experience various sufferings, cry out in distress, and think of ways to escape, but they will be unable to do so.
Such bitter and unwholesome karma is created by the deluded themselves;
It is like a raging fire burning a forest, and all the grasses and trees have no way to escape.
Evil karma is also like this. One cycles through hell and experiences various sufferings, unable to escape them.

If there are people who abandon evil friends, do not commit misdeeds, understand cause and effect, free themselves from doubts and denials, cultivate right views, have faith and joy in suchness, and seek peace and happiness, far from the cycle of birth and death and all sufferings, this is unsurpassed and incomparable.

Without characteristics, without activity, free from false inversion, with permanence, bliss, self, and purity, with mastery and unobstructedness, free from all bonds, good and bad karma, all of which are far removed.
